displayed_text: Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: There’s probably, I think there’s only like seven or eight of these proton sites around the country. So ah Family Member: I think B___ is one of them. Doctor: Oh, yeah, B___’s up. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I mean we were, you know, supposed to get one up in F___. I don’t know what’s going to happen with that but nonetheless B___ is right here. Family Member: But say if his rib spots start- causing him pain - Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Family Member: Can they go in specifically with a proton or? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Would it be needed, a proton be needed, or can regular radiation take care of it? Doctor: So typically it’s just regular radiation. So right now as far as I’m aware it’s sort of like isolated rib treatment for proton is not commonplace. Family Member: Mm Hmm.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I can’t tell ya. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, unless we stick a needle into the bone and say, “Does cancer come out?” Patient: Right. Doctor: Or is this just a hole there? And, so, part of me has to figure out from what you are saying is - is it better or not better. You know, what’s different? You know, clearly under here, I feel like a quarter. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, and is that just a swollen gland from inflammation that’s coming there. Cancer really shouldn’t give you a gland. You know, unless that gland is involved. Um, but that’s where the normal prostate cancer goes. It goes to the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I can’t, I’m not judging. I don’t know what that is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Your CAT scan, uh, says that there’s more, uh, there’s more scarring at the bone sites. Patient: Mm, hmm.

Patient: Okay you know the pills you gave me before you gave me that the other ones, the crazy ones. Doctor: Oh yeah Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Them was them was alright. Doctor: I’ll give you those. (pause) Patient: Yeah ‘cause the ones you gave me you prescribed they was they was they jumped out of my skin. Doctor: What is his uh… Healthcare Professional: Those and morphine sixty Doctor: No he gets a breakthrough also right? Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Patient: I shoulda brought the… I shoulda brought the pill bottle with me. Doctor: Yeah, okay. So morphine is sixty huh? Can I stick with the same doses? We don’t need to change anything do we of the pain medicine?

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: We have seen some nausea in some people. We have some seen some rash, you know a few people ten to fifteen percent. Um we are going to keep a very close eye on your liver function and kidney function to make sure that those weren’t affected by the drug. Uh some people have a uh worsening of their hot flashes, because of the Xtandi itself cause worsening of the hot flashes. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um some people can have a uh decreased energy or they might feel more tired. Um but I, I would have to say in general these side effects are all better than what we see in chemotherapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: So it it it does seem to be the best Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: What I would like to do, is uh I would like to leave you with this information. Please don’t read it now because I want you to take your time with it. Um it’s it’s pretty intense reading but if if you take it slowly, and then maybe you have people in your family with you, going over it with you. Um and then in in about a week um we will call you back up. I will have my research nurse reach out to you by telephone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And uh see what you think. By then we will have the information from the PSA. And if the PSA is rising again, it it would be my recommendation that at the very least we start the Xtandi. And then addition to that, possibly to consider the clinical trial. But at the very least, I do think Xtandi is going to be a part of your treatment. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And if the PSA has somehow stabilized or dropped on its own, which I don’t anticipate in this case-

Family Member: I had a question about if it does cause nausea (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Does that last the full three weeks or does it taper off? Doctor: Oh no. Most – I would not expect you to have significant nausea at all. I am going to give you a prescription on you know Zofran in case you need it. But most people don’t need more than what we give them today, right. Okay, so it’s not expected. Once in a while I guess if you have a major reaction, it’s okay to have it - Family Member: And so - Doctor: My hope is if this is a lot of this flare-up from the pain from the cancer, then actually we should start seeing an improvement ah without having to do - Patient: Well, that’s what I didn’t know was - Doctor: You know, and what raised my bar of suspicion is how much of this adrenal mass grew. Doctor: If the same kind of growth is happening in the bones, then you know it sort of took off all of a sudden, frankly. Family Member: Uh hum, right. Doctor: That made me think maybe the rest of your pain, also this big pain flare-up that you’re experiencing might be problematic Patient: Well see that’s - Doctor: But bone disease is always very hard to see.

Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Um the reality is that we have tried that in the past and we still do that on occasion in certain patients. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: All the lymph nodes are connected to each other by so-called lymphatic system - Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and so the the the concern about targeting one particular lymph node or maybe two lymph nodes or three lymph nodes is is that um you might only be affecting you know ten percent, fifteen percent, thirty percent of the cancer cells in your body. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So you’re going after them just because you can see it but there is no guarantee that what we can see on the CAT scan is the only place at this point in time where the cancer is at. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: So we might graph that lymph node and your PSA might drop by fifteen percent, then we’ll know in retrospect had we got that lymph node we might have actually killed all of the cells in that lymph node - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and yet your PSA might drop by fifteen or twenty-five percent. And so what we’ve learnt the hard way, so-to-speak with experience, is that although we can do that, it is technically feasible -um and there are some types of radiation that can be reimbursed by insurance companies, for example -

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I still would want at least one or two weeks off of the abiraterone before I would get started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you, you know, end up telling me, you know, this doesn’t make sense for me. Huh, we might make the decision when you’re back in a month, huh, and then we can go from there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you need a refill on your morphine? Or are you good? Patient: No. I’m good with the morphine. Doctor: Okay. And you’ve been emailing me? Who’s been writing the pain people? Who’s been doing that for you? Patient: What? Doctor: When you need a refill. Patient: Huh, I call R___. Doctor: Okay. But then they need a doctor to sign it. Patient: Yeah. Hum, that, but I call R___ about, huh, that. Oh. I don’t know. That , it ran out. They sent it seven days too early, and there’s no refills. That’s what I’m saying about, starting seven days early, but I still need them, and I need

Patient: Yeah. Very. His name is D_, too. Doctor: Oh, okay. Well ---- Patient: He’s named for my son, I’m sure. She likes him a lot better than me. Family Member: That’s not clear. That’s – Doctor: Well, it looks like the PSA came down again. Patient: It came down a little bit. Doctor: Down to one point five. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think we’re probably hitting the bottom. Uh, which is okay. I, I think we have to sort of see how long we live there. Um. The, uh, the other thing that came back was your DNA test. Patient: The genetics. Doctor: Yeah, did you see that or not? Patient: No! I didn’t get a copy that I’m aware of. Uh, did you get it? Doctor: Yeah. So, it actually looks like, uh, (coughs)

Patient: I think so. Doctor: On that one? Patient: Right, but the ones do you remember… Doctor: Yeah, yeah, but those though they don’t agree with you huh? The effects are… Patient: Yeah, the ones you gave me before that I think it was for… Doctor: The Megnace. Patient: Yeah I think that was for you know for throwing up or something like that. I take them because I took them and then it always worked. Like when I be feeling like nauseous I’ll throw up, I’ll take one of them and then I I cool down. But them other ones they Doctor: They didn’t agree with you. Patient: They made me want to jump out of my skin and run up the street. Doctor: That’s too bad, yeah. That’s scary. Doctor: Okay, so let’s give him then Patient: Wooh. Healthcare Professional: So

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm. So, that would be sort of, in some ways, a gamble. But, some folks, everything we know about the drugs you’ve had so far, we’ve had people gamble at one point. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And, then, the third one is we draw blood tests today, just to see the AR-V7 positive. That maybe that you say in what you’re doing now, and if you are AR-V7 positive, then we can sort of say, “Hey, yeah, let’s look at this other option,” if the immune therapy would be something that you would think about. Patient: Okay. What, what, what’s the, uh, uh, um likelihood of, of, if at that time the AR-V7, uh, testing comes back negative which means I can’t do that. Doctor: Right. Patient: Uh, and then look at the other options. So, is that, is the one that is phase one is that, that window like a real tight window. That seven days from now, it’s gonna be closed? Doctor: Umm. I don’t know that. So, when I spoke to Dr. P_, all she let me know was that there was a slot. You know, that would be something that we would say once you’ve decided or that we’ve given you the consent form that we have a potential patient who’s interested, that they would save that slot for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they would, I assume, that there is going to need to be a twenty-eight day washout of your current therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, maybe that you have to repeat scans prior to that. Um, the adrenal glands. The, the big wild card there right now what I can clearly state that it is not specific. I don’t know what it is.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: That, that’s, okay. Doctor: Uh, the, uh, the idea of those drugs. It depends on which of the drugs. There’s a bunch of different HIV drugs. I can’t remember which one you mentioned. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of those drugs block the DNA in certain ways, but in the virus, mostly. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of them block enzymes that the virus makes. And I think those things may also block cancer enzymes, is what they- Patient: Is what the trick is? Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Uh, anyway, I’ll, I’ll- Patient: Yeah. If you get a chance. Doctor: Will think about that. Okay. Patient: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. So I will try to get a hold of you Friday.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: In order to keep you on this study, uh, from the side effect perspective, we’re going to need to temporarily stop the medication again, unfortunately- Because of this hemoglobin being eight point nine. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it’s very likely that when you come back on September fifth, your hemoglobin will be above nine, hopefully, above ten, it will recover some, in other words, uh, and then given that the hemoglobin has improved, we can put you back on the medication, but it will be at the two-hundred milligram dose. It’ll be a second level of dose reduction. Okay? Patient: Hum. Doctor: I don’t think you’ll need to go lower than that. Okay? But I think the two-fifty in terms of the anemia, uh, it did cause the same problem, again, to a lesser degree, but it did still cause the same problem. Uh, so my preference, if you want to remain on the study, which I think is reasonable, would be as of today to ask you to stop the medication until you come back and see us on September the fifth. And on that day, what we’re probably going to recommend, provided that your hemoglobin has increased again, preferably above ten, but at least above nine, is we’re going to put you back on the second dose level reduction which will be two hundred milligrams per day. Patient: Hum. Okay. Family Member: So between now and September fifth, a week-? Doctor: That’s, that’s two weeks. Yeah. Family Member: Does he go in for another blood transfusion or are you expecting the hemoglobin to increase pretty much on its own as he regulates without the medication? Doctor: One idea would be to check a hemoglobin level at a local laboratory, uh, one week from now just to see where we are at. And if it has made significant progress on its own, we can skip the blood transfusion. And if it looks like it’s only gone up like one-tenth of a point, then we can perhaps schedule a blood transfusion before September fifth. So if you agree to that, I can give you, uh, a prescription for a complete blood count. Patient: Okay.

Healthcare Professional: Is it thirty days as before? In those terms I don’t know- Doctor: We’ll, we’ll see. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Okay. Perfect. Doctor: And so I will be in touch by the end of the week to tell you what I’ve, what I’ve learned. Okay? Patient: Alright. Thank you. Doctor: So just for, for now, Germany, I get what they want, the test results, uh, I’ll see what the policy says about you know just paying for, for the drugs. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Can I just inject on the Cornell thing? Clinical trials seem to me like they are very regimen and very time consuming, and I don’t think your situation gives you that. So if you’re willing to do Germany why would you spend this time looking at Germany connection, I mean the Cornell connection, when we’re pretty sure about Germany? I just don’t want to waste your Doctor: Well, you know, if it’s the same drug, which it is, and it’s you know and- Patient: And it’s available. Doctor: You may not care that I’m saving you fifty to hundred thousand dollars but it’s those, those things. Family Member: No. But I’m just very uh the anxiety of the whole thing is, is he - Doctor: I mean the Cornell group has a lot of experience giving you know radioactive compounds, just not for this one, because they’re just starting to do it, so they’ve probably treated a thousand people, maybe they treated three or four hundred people. No wonder that matters. It’s just giving somebody radioactive stuff and making sure after that happens part of it does that big of a difference, uh?

Patient: Uh, I don’t know, I guess I’d be alright. I’m back walking. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I couldn’t walk then. It got bad. Doctor: Gosh. Patient: I went to the hospital. Doctor: Yeah. Gosh. Could you, uh, uh breathe without oxygen? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah? That was okay? Patient: They put a, they put a little thing in the nose. Doctor: Okay. But I see you don’t need it. So that’s a good sign. Did they give antibiotics while you were there? Patient: Not, not with me. Family Member: Not to take home.

Patient: Yeah. I don’t understand it. Doctor: I think it’s, it’s, well, because the earth’s a circle, globe. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Oh. Oh. Doctor: If you fly straight it’s longer. Patient: Right. Oh. Doctor: Because I don’t quite understand it. Patient: I didn’t know that. Doctor: But, yeah, like when you fly- Patient: I was trying to- Doctor: Like when you fly to Europe, you kind of fly up over, like if you’re going to England, you fly up over Greenland and down. Patient: Yeah. That’s what they did. That’s exactly what they did. Doctor: It’s shorter somehow. Patient: Yeah.
